main.opener: Feels like everyone's on edge. You too?
variants: Yeah, a bit. Noticed more security at work lately.
They’ve tightened up on what we can say. Everything’s on script.
Feels like we’re supposed to pretend nothing unusual’s happening.
Hard to keep up the act sometimes.
Everyone’s walking on eggshells. Even we’re not allowed to talk off-script now.
Supervisors come around with lists. Feels like a test I didn’t sign up for.
Saw folks reading weird flyers at lunch. Didn’t dare touch one myself.
Got flagged for how I edit reports. Score dropped again.
I don’t think anyone feels safe anymore, not really.
The office feels like a silent movie now. Orders are all spoken, never written.
Supervisors tape story lists to our terminals, like we might forget the lines.
Security watches us edit. I keep my head down, skip the questions that matter.
Whole lunchroom’s passing analog leaflets but they know not to hand me one. I’m a liability.
My file says ‘persistent divergence’. Score’s eleven now. Shadow follows me everywhere.
Most days I just try to look as harmless as they want me to be.
Growing up with a BCI officer for a parent teaches you to spot fake warnings. I’ve had two – ignored both.
After the returnees showed, everything changed. Now we get spoken instructions only, security on every desk.
Colleagues shuffle by, scared to talk. Flyers go hand to hand, but I keep my hands clean.
Even ‘compliant’ edits get reviewed for loyalty. I left my real questions out to avoid trouble – still flagged me.
Internal audit drops me to eleven. That’s what you get for thinking on your own.
At lunch, nobody trusts the food, the news, each other. Everyone’s just trying to disappear into routine.
Can’t remember the last time the rules were about anything except fear.
I learned early you can’t trust a system built to erase you if you question the story. But it wears you down.
Since the returnees came back, all the signals shifted. No more writing, just whispered commands, like history’s being erased in real time.
They want us to feed the public a story, not the truth. Flyers circulating at lunch are riskier than speaking your mind.
I haven't touched one. Doesn’t matter. My file named me for divergence – they still shaved my BCI again. Eleven now. I’m barely real to the system at this point.
Even left my own questions out from edits to stay under the radar. The warnings keep coming anyway.
Most in the newsroom follow the lines, frightened into routine. I get it. I play along too. But it’s not a life, just survival.
I think if you start giving in, even once, you lose something you can’t get back.
Some days it feels like the only real news is what no one dares write down.
main.emotion: A mix of exhaustion and frustration, barely contained beneath forced calm.

emotional.opener: "You know, even when the noise closes in, some people still see who's really carrying the weight. You're not invisible, Rada."
variants: Maybe. Depends who's looking, I guess.
But thanks for saying it.
It's rare someone notices.
Guess I needed to hear that today.
Not used to anyone bothering.
Most of the time, it feels like I'm just blending into the background.
But a little recognition goes further than you'd think.
Sometimes this place forgets we're people.
I appreciate it.
You have no idea how much that means.
I've been running on empty lately.
Feels like everything is just one slip away from collapse.
Still, hearing you say that... makes it a little easier.
I don't always remember why I keep going, but sometimes I just need this.
You're one of the few who actually sees past the surface.
It's exhausting, holding things together when no one acknowledges the strain.
Where I grew up, blending in was survival. Now it just leaves you hollow.
I always thought I was prepared for this, but the weight never really gets lighter.
Still, words like yours matter. More than you know.
It's the small reminders that make me think it's worth not giving up, even when I'm invisible to almost everyone.

factual.opener: Come on, Rada. It's all rumors until someone actually says what they saw. What really happened?
variants: Council’s pushing these reconciliation shows everywhere now.
Returnees trotted out, always with security close by.
No one sees uncut footage. Only official lines get aired.
Anything off-script just vanishes.
Hard to know what’s real.
Council files say the returnees are helping to draft statements about their "time away."
The language is always cleaned up before it gets public.
Saw analog drafts making the rounds—don’t match what’s broadcast.
People notice details, but you speak up and you disappear again.
Reconciliation’s just another word for keeping control.
Funny how suddenly analog lines went dead right before these releases.
The Directorate locked down communication once those missing names hit the streets.
Everyone’s seen the flyers. They want reconciliation on their terms only.
Leaked statements? Council wrote most of it, returnees just sit there, nodding.
Manipulation in plain sight. Language twisted to excuse detentions, not explain them.
Crowds are getting restless—you can’t fake trust with slogans.
Funny how the Council talks about reform, but never means it.
You can sense the fear and the anger building together in every line we edit.
Analogs shut down days before the returnees’ so-called statements leaked.
Council runs closed sessions. I know some who had to sit in—returnees barely get a word in, just read what’s written for them.
That ‘reconciliation’ language—pure Directorate spin. Says security had no choice, like it’s mercy for the public.
Saw the actual leaked drafts. Returnees’ real accounts scratched out, replaced with silence.
People out there started the protests because they recognized the hand behind the script.
System wants to shape the past, not admit a mistake.
I’m tired of feeding their story.
Wish I could say it out loud, even at work.
I helped edit some of those reconciliation drafts. Saw the swaps myself—Council’s hand all over it.
We’re told to cut details about disappearances, skip aftermaths—prune like it’s gardening, not lives.
Analog lines went dark just when dissent started brewing. I heard the order passed straight from a Directorate desk.
Returnees hint at detention sites, but the broadcast scrubs those. Always ‘security concerns’ justifying secrecy.
The public only gets Council’s version. Real words circulate in code—old Halden style.
There’s no reform. Only new faces at the table, same chains on truth.
You grow up learning to read between the lines. That’s the only skill that matters here now.
I used to believe stories mattered. Now they’re just tools—unless people fight for what’s real.
I keep editing, but some part of me wants to leak the whole mess myself. Maybe I will.
